subject: Re: [junit] Best Practice for Tests ?
msgSnippet: ... That s what I do and it works extremely well. Sure, if you change the package of a class, you need to remember to change the package of the test class, but
messageBody:
> Steven Webster wrote:
>
> 1. A separate directory tree with a root note of test, the package
> structure of which reflects that of the codebase; keep the tests
> completely isolated from production code, the downside being that if I
> refactor code around packages, I have to remember to move tests as well;
> also, removes my ability to test private and protected methods..

That's what I do and it works extremely well. Sure, if you change the package
of a class, you need to remember to change the package of the test class, but
if you are very strict about test first development you should have no problem
keeping the tests and codebase packages in alignment. This technique does NOT
remove the ability to test protected methods. Classes in the same package can
access package, protected, and public methods of each other.

There was a big discussion recently about how to test private methods. Read
the thread starting here:
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/junit/message/1267?threaded=1

> 2. A 'test' directory in each package of the codebase, containing
> TestXXXX classes

Yuck. This would work okay, but my personal preference is to keep test code
separate from production code. Same comment as above for protected and private
methods

> 3. Actually make each class in the production code it's own test, ie put
> the JUnit testing code in the class itself.

Double yuck for the same reason as 2, I prefer not to mix test source code and
production source code. It actually wouldn't be that hard to separate the test
class from the production class; you would code the test class as an inner
class. If you follow a good naming convention, it would be relatively easy to
separate the test class files from the codebase class files. (It doesn't
matter whether or not you can easily separate the source, it's the class files
that matter). The only advantage to this is that it allows you test private
methods. Again, refer to the archives for the discussion of testing private
methods.
